Description: Terracotta figure of Harpokrates. Harpokrates standing on a plain, flat-fronted plinth and leaning on a short pier, with base and capital indicated. His finger is to his mouth and he has a cornucopia in the crook of his left arm. He wears a long chiton reaching to his ankles and apparently a longer undergarment; his himation is rolled up and encircles his waist, and he has a low-slung belt, running diagonally from his left hip to below his right hip, with a long decorated end hanging down in front. His head is shaven except for a sidelock and he has a tightly woven and bound wreath with ties hanging to his shoulders, surmounted by a Double Crown. The back is plain with a circular vent. Hollow; two-piece mould. Micaceous brown Nile silt, with traces on the front of a white dressing.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Comparanda. Close: Breccia 1934: no. 59; Leonard 2001: pl. 3.3, fr. from Naukratis, context third to first century bc? Near: Kaufmann 1913: fig. 28:17. For the clothing, see also 3066.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3046)
Acquisition name: Donated by: Mrs B C Shuckburgh
